    Advanced topics A real world example

    A real world example

    real-world-example.Rmd

    This is practically the same code you can find on this blog post of mine: https://www.brodrigues.co/blog/2018-11-14-luxairport/ but with some minor updates to reflect the current state of the tidyverse packages as well as logging using {loud}.

    library(loud)
#> Loading required package: rlang
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(tidyr)
library(stringr)
library(lubridate)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'lubridate'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     date, intersect, setdiff, union
library(readr)

l_r_tsv <- loudly(read_tsv)

airline <- l_r_tsv("http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/estat-navtree-portlet-prod/BulkDownloadListing?file=data/avia_gor_fr.tsv.gz")
#> Rows: 8189 Columns: 338
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: "\t"
#> chr (338): unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\time, 2021Q1, 2021M04, 2021M03, 2021M02, 20...
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Define required functions

l_select <- loudly(select)
l_pivot_longer <- loudly(pivot_longer)
l_filter <- loudly(filter)
l_mutate <- loudly(mutate)
l_separate <- loudly(separate)
l_group_by <- loudly(group_by)
l_summarise <- loudly(summarise)
    avia_clean <- airline %>%
  bind_loudly(l_select, "unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\\time", contains("20")) %>%
  bind_loudly(l_pivot_longer, -`unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\\time`, names_to = "date", values_to = "passengers") %>%
  bind_loudly(l_separate,
              col = `unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\\time`,
              into = c("unit", "tra_meas", "air_pr\\time"),
              sep = ",")

    Let’s focus on monthly data:

    avia_monthly <- avia_clean %>%
  bind_loudly(l_filter,
              tra_meas == "PAS_BRD_ARR",
              !is.na(passengers),
              str_detect(date, "M")) %>%
  bind_loudly(l_mutate,
              date = paste0(date, "01"),
              date = ymd(date)) %>%
  bind_loudly(l_select,
              destination = "air_pr\\time", date, passengers)

    Now that the data is clean, we can take a look at the log and see what was done:

    
avia_monthly %>%
  pick("log")
#> [1] "Log start..."                                                                                                                                                                      
#> [2] "read_tsv(http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/estat-navtree-portlet-prod/BulkDownloadListing?file=data/avia_gor_fr.tsv.gz) started at 2022-02-19 15:18:48 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:18:50"
#> [3] "select(.l$result,unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\\time,contains(\"20\")) started at 2022-02-19 15:18:50 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:18:50"                                                    
#> [4] "pivot_longer(.l$result,-`unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\\\\time`,date,passengers) started at 2022-02-19 15:18:50 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:18:50"                                          
#> [5] "separate(.l$result,`unit,tra_meas,airp_pr\\\\time`,c(\"unit\", \"tra_meas\", \"air_pr\\\\time\"),,) started at 2022-02-19 15:18:50 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:19:51"               
#> [6] "filter(.l$result,tra_meas == \"PAS_BRD_ARR\",!is.na(passengers),str_detect(date, \"M\")) started at 2022-02-19 15:19:51 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:19:53"                          
#> [7] "mutate(.l$result,paste0(date, \"01\"),ymd(date)) started at 2022-02-19 15:19:51 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:19:53"                                                                  
#> [8] "select(.l$result,air_pr\\time,date,passengers) started at 2022-02-19 15:19:51 and ended at 2022-02-19 15:19:53"

    This is especially useful if the object avia_monthly gets saved using saveRDS(). People that then read this object, can read the log to know what happened and reproduce the steps if necessary.

    Developed by Bruno Rodrigues.
